titleStmt.title: M1-8, 7 of 10. [If you have read this brittle & imperfect sketch...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 27-32. 6p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8-7. [If you have read this brittle & imperfect sketch...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 27-32. 6p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.s: It is time that another attitude

Suppose that for a moment we cease to
concern ourselves with the sequence in time,
there is another way of looking at these famous
monuments.

div.p:
The critic, we must admit, is a one of the least
real of writers, the most inhibited the most
restricted. of writers On the one hand Suppose he
attempts to convey his own impression –
so often his emotion runs counter to his reason.
The pressure
This [naked?] & imperfect sketch leaves requires to be

p.s:
You will complain that this rushed &
imperfect sketch has shown you nothing of the
real force behind this th these famous
monuments. Let us for a moment then look
at them from a different angle.
It is a charge that can be levelled against all
out criticism. For though the reader who
For the critic has No sooner has the pen
touched the page, than there rise up
so many of those influences which
are hostile to the transmission of
the emotion.

div.p:
Let us then attempt what for one brief moment
that very dangerous transition: from one
attitude of mind to another. In this case
from the omniscient to the fallible. It is
& admit in the first place, that the
scene we cannot say have the creative
impulse, save by giving experience to it
ourselves. Thus the time Therefore when we
talk of the plays of And as anybody
knows who has written even a short story
the creative impulse is only to be stated in its
own terms. If then we want to convey
any notion So Talk It is undeniable
that the creation of a work of art by some one else
produces something an emotion in us.
And the origin of [illeg.] is the desire to in
in the first place [illeg.] to transmit this emotion
& then to explain it. The difficulties that
make this an impossible undertaking.
Take, as a simple instance, the quotation
This In order to copy out even one stage of a
play, it is necessary to open at the right
page then to copy accurately. This
at once breaks the stream of thought. Besides,
there is always present the other critic –
Let us see him in person – a For ever

so many years, he has not been later than nine at the [illeg.].

subservience to the fact to free ourselves from
all the [impositions?] of authority &
the dominion of what is customary.
How often to say openly that there is
nothing doing. There is to slip into
all these are done force that diminish, distort

The streets are drab enough. The
river has a great turbulent swollen
stream. The cranes are picking sacks from
the holds of ships. There is a

shiny slab of mud beneath the warehouses; &
rises. The gulls are swooping; & some small boys
paddle in the pebbles. Above the sky is
huddled & crowded with purple streamers.
We are still thinking of the plays, because
it was here that the stood. Now let us
give way to the imagination. After all
what are four hundred years. We can

p.s:
This is particularly true today; when
the [economic?] force is cutting the critic into
a special force.

div.p:
For then we revive the reader – a very
impatient person. The For the reader was
born when the playhouse closed.

This brittle & imperfect sketch, with its exaggerations &
foreshortenings, serves to bring out only the shapes of
certain prominent objects; but & To convey
The & that perhaps so partially that they are
unrecognisable. Its implications can [illeg.]
pointed out by removing for a moment, the
critical attitude; & talking for a moment
as Let us talk for a moment without the book.
Let us look at the critical position &
discover why it is so alien to the private
position. In the first place the critic is
infallible. But in order to adress this attitude he has
to stiffen himself a more supple method [illeg.]
needed. If we could return to the age of
innocence: if we could talk, if we could
even write a letter to a friend about .
Indeed the som deplore some way of
preserving those natural exclamations.

But wecome, at the end; when so much has
been said so much said so much known:
so great a human effort has been
expended. In order to provide us
with our knowledge, many lives have been
passed in coal mines: And tho the
result is often of no importance, we must
repeat the effort. A great
[anti?] room separates us from the
